titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert E. Butts Papers, 1908-1997 ASP.2000.01
titlestmt.author: Mary Margaret Fletcher.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-03-16 12:57:59 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Robert E. Butts Papers
did.abstract: Robert Earl Butts was a philosopher of science whose research interests included the work of Leibniz, Newton, Galileo, Whewell, and Kant. He spent most of his career as a faculty member at the University of Western Ontario and was active in professional organizations and publications in the history and philosophy of science. The papers consist of biographical materials, including educational documents, early writings and schoolwork, photographs, correspondence, and memorabilia; and professional materials, including correspondence, research and lecture notes, records of publications and professional organizations, and unpublished drafts.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Robert Earl Butts was born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, in 1928 and died in 1997 in London, Ontario, Canada. After attending Manheim Township High School from 1943-1947, he earned his A.B. and A.M. in philosophy from Syracuse University in 1951 and 1952, respectively, and his PhD from the University of Pennsylvania in 1957. He joined the philosophy department at the University of Western Ontario in 1963, where he would remain until his death. He also lectured at a number of prestigious institutions through fellowships and visiting appointments, including the University of Pittsburgh's Center for Philosophy of Science.

Butts was an active author and researcher in the field of history and philosophy of science and was deeply involved in his professional community, maintaining close personal and professional relationships with many prominent philosophers of his time. He edited and authored monographs on Whewell, Newton, Galileo, and Kant, as well as contributing prolifically to professional journals, anthologies, and encyclopedias. He served as editor-in-chief of Philosophy of Science from 1980-1990, and was managing editor of the University of Western Ontario Series in Philosophy of Science from 1979 until his death. He was chairman of the Canadian National Committee of the International Union of History and Philosophy of Science from 1978 to 1991, and was an active member of many other professional organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following four series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Robert Earl Butts Papers document Butts' life and work as an academic in the field of scientific philosophy during the latter half of the twentieth century. Biographical materials consist of documents concerning Butts' personal life as a son, brother, husband, father, and friend. There is particular emphasis on his early life in Pennsylvania and his education at Manheim Township High School, with a less significant amount of memorabilia relating to his later life.

The larger body of professional papers contains material concerning Butts' active involvement in his community of academic peers. He played a leadership role in a number of national and international professional organizations and conferences, as well as writing and editing numerous publications and serving as a mentor to many of his peers and students. His papers document these and other functions that he carried out as a faculty member and philosopher.

The collection consists primarily of paper documents housed in legal-sized document boxes. Box 7 contains photographs, mostly family portraits from Butts' early life. Box 28 contains a variety of alternative media, mainly cassette tapes and floppy disks, much of the content of which is unknown. Box 29 contains oversized documents such as diplomas and certificates. Materials are arranged either chronologically or alphabetically where possible. Untitled, undated, or miscellaneous materials are generally found at the end of the folder or file group. Additional scope and content notes are provided at the series and subseries level.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Robert Earl Butts Papers, 1908-1997, ASP.2000.01, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert Earl Butts Papers, 1908-1997, ASP.2000.01, Archives of Scientific Philosophy, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Valentine Watson Rodgers in May 2000.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Nicholas Rescher Papers, 1957-2005, ASP.2009.01, Archives of Scientific Philosophy, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Rebecca Crago in Summer 2010 and by Mary Margaret Fletcher in Fall 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Portions of the collection (approximately 2 linear feet) that contain personally identifiable, private, confidential, or sensitive information have been physically removed and are closed indefinitely to public access. This includes private correspondence between Butts and his family as well as legal and medical records and material containing confidential information about students and colleagues.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

did.unittitle: Biographical Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to Butts' upbringing, his personal life, and his relationships and activities outside of the professional community. Many of the documents are from the period of approximately 1943 to 1952, which encompasses Butts' high school and undergraduate education. During this time, he was active in school and community activities such as Key Club, theater, student government, and the high school newspaper. From 1944-1945, Butts corresponded with his brother, who was stationed on the European front of World War II. He was also an avid writer in his youth; a number of folders and notebooks in this series are dedicated to poetry and prose that Butts wrote during his high school and college years.

The material from Butts' later life in this series is concentrated on memorabilia such as invitations and newspaper clippings pertaining both to events in Butts' own life and current events and topics that were of interest to him. There is also a large group of brochures and guides from his travels in Europe during the 1980s and 1990s.

did.unittitle: Educational Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of report cards and other administrative materials relating to Butts' education at the various institutions described above. Some material, mainly consisting of diplomas and other educational certificates, has been removed due to size restrictions and placed in Box 29.

did.unittitle: Report Cards
Educational Documents from Syracuse
Schoolwork and Early Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Butts' development as a writer and scholar from high school through his years as a graduate student at Penn and Syracuse. It includes formal assignments as well as personal reflections and creative projects. The material in this series is unpublished and predates Butts' formal work as an academic researcher.

did.unittitle: Notes and Assignments

Memorabilia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The items in this subseries document the broad variety of Butt's private activities and interests. Over the course of his life, he collected newspaper clippings documenting achievements and milestones for himself and his family, as well as some current events and general topics of interest; programs and brochures from various events he participated in or attended; and maps, brochures, and souvenirs from his travels, especially those in Europe during the 1970s, 80s, and 90s. This subseries also includes items such as report cards and yearbooks that belonged to Butts' father and older brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists mostly of correspondence that occurred between his widow and grieving family, friends, and colleagues after Butt's sudden death in 1997. Also included are some funeral plans and copies of obituaries from various publications.

did.unittitle: Letters from Valentine Watson Rodgers to Friends, Family, and Colleagues
Obituaries and Funeral Plans
Condolences (Notes and Cards)
Condolences (Letters and Emails)
Personal Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this subseries is mostly of a general nature, consisting of notes, letters, and cards that Butts exchanged with various family members and friends over the course of his life. Of particular note are the 1944-1945 letters from his older brother, who was stationed in Europe during World War II. Due to their private and/or sensitive nature, a large number of documents from this subseries are included in the restricted material described at the beginning of this finding aid.

Christmas Cards
Birthday Cards (Mostly 60th)
Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Most of the photographs in this subseries are family photographs from Butts' youth, including both studio portraits and candids, and group photos of student organizations from his time at Manheim Township High School. Images that hung framed in his office, many of them of Kant, comprise another significant portion of this subseries. Of particular note is the baby book that Butts' parents filled out for him shortly after his birth in 1928; an infant's knit garment in excellent condition was found tucked into the back cover and remains in the file.

Professional Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents pertaining to Butts' life and work as a researcher, author, and active member of his professional community. The papers in this series document Butt's longtime involvement in a variety of professional activities and the respect and camaraderie he enjoyed among his academic peers. The largest portion of this series is dedicated to unpublished drafts of works authored by both Butts and his peers; he was frequently consulted as both an official referee and an informal colleague.

Researchers will notice the same names and subjects appearing in multiple locations throughout the series; this is due to the intimate nature of the field of scientific philosophy, in which the same actors appear as journal contributors, book editors, grant applicants, committee members, and close personal friends at various points in Butt's life.

did.unittitle: Research, Writing, and Publication

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Butts was active as both an author and editor of publications in the field of scientific philosophy. These functions are also closely related to his role as a researcher and an academic. This subseries consists of a broad variety of materials that document these interrelated professional functions. Of particular note is the extensive correspondence with authors and editors that Butts conducted in his capacity as editor of the Western Ontario Series in Philosophy of Science, published by Reidel and later Kluwer Academic Publishers from 1973-1996, which is arranged chronologically in Section 1 of the subseries. This is distinct from the correspondence in Section 3, which relates to individual works that Butts personally wrote or edited. Also significant is the large number of unpublished drafts of Butts' academic work found in Section 2.

did.unittitle: Publications Edited by Butts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This section contains two groups of material: correspondence and administrative records related to the publications that Butts oversaw, and reviews of those publications. The latter are listed according to the author of the work being reviewed.

Teaching

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The items in this subseries document Butts' function as an instructor and faculty member at various institutions, particularly the University of Western Ontario. The majority of the documents pertaining to the courses that Butts taught are in the form of teaching notes, handouts, and syllabi (Section 1). Also included is a small amount of correspondence and other administrative records that relate to Butts' employment and his role as a member of the university community outside of his academic function.

Professional Organizations and Conferences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence, newsletters, pamphlets, financial records, meeting minutes, and other items that document Butts' active role in his professional community. He served on boards and in leadership positions for several of the professional organizations and conferences represented in these records, notably chairing several committees of the International Union of the History and Philosophy of Science during the 1970s and 1980s. He was particularly active in the international philosophical community, organizing and attending conferences in Europe, Canada, and the United States throughout his career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Butts played an active role as a colleague and friend to other researchers and academics in his field. He was sought after as a reviewer of academic publications and grant proposals as well as a reference for colleagues and students. The material in Section 1, which consists of applications, CVs, and correspondence, documents these functions. Both subgroups in this subseries are arranged by individual's surname, though Section 2 consists of unpublished drafts rather than administrative materials.

did.unittitle: References and Reviews

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The items in this section are arranged by individual. Each individual's file may contain a variety of documents pertaining to Butts' role as a mentor and referee for his students and colleagues in their careers and publishing endeavors. This includes reference and referee requests, as well as applications, CVs/resumes, manuscripts, proposals, and any other material that may have been enclosed with Butts' correspondence on the subject. Note that all letters of reference and personally identifiable or confidential information have been removed and restricted.

Professional Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of general correspondence between Butts and his professional peers and colleagues. Material is arranged alphabetically by correspondent, including both individuals and organizations, and ranges from one letter to exchanges taking place over several years or decades, as with friend and colleague Jurgen Mittelstrass of the University of Konstanz.

Multimedia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The content of the materials in this series is mostly unknown, since they are largely stored on outdated multimedia formats that cannot currently be read by this department. The labels that Butts placed on his floppy disks, which appear to contain backups of his personal computer, indicate that some of the contents may be alternative drafts or supplemental materials to documents found in the paper portion of the collection (e.g. lectures, documentation from professional organizations). The most readily accessible materials are the audio cassette tapes, which mainly contain recordings of radio appearances that Butts made and dictated correspondence during the time of his hospitalization during the 1970s.

Oversized Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of oversized materials that have been separated from the collection proper for storage purposes. It contains a small number of documents, most of which are diplomas and certificates that are biographical in nature. The first document, the certificate from the Weigh-House at Oudewater, is from a historical site in the Netherlands where accused witches were weighed and certified as non-witches during medieval witch hunts, a subject of research interest in Butts' later life.
